Literature Review: Wolbachia, a widespread endosymbiotic bacterium found in arthropods and nematodes, has garnered significant attention in the field of molecular biology due to its unique ability to manipulate host reproduction. This literature review focuses on the molecular mechanisms underlying cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI), the most common reproductive manipulation induced by Wolbachia.Cytoplasmic incompatibility is a phenomenon where Wolbachia-infected males are incompatible with uninfected females or females infected with a different Wolbachia strain, resulting in embryonic lethality. This reproductive manipulation provides a selective advantage to Wolbachia-infected females, facilitating the spread of the bacteria through host populations (Werren et al., 2008).Recent advances in molecular biology have shed light on the genetic basis of CI. Beckmann et al. (2017) identified two genes, cifA and cifB, which form a toxin-antidote system responsible for CI. The cifB gene encodes a deubiquitylase (DUB) or nuclease that acts as a toxin when introduced into the host egg by infected sperm. The cifA gene product serves as the antidote, rescuing embryonic development when present in infected females.The discovery of the cif genes has led to two main hypotheses explaining the molecular mechanism of CI: the toxin-antidote model and the host-modification model. The toxin-antidote model proposes that CifB acts as a toxin in the male germline, which is neutralized by CifA in infected females. In contrast, the host-modification model suggests that CifB modifies host factors in the male germline, which are then rescued by CifA in infected females (Shropshire et al., 2018).Interestingly, the involvement of deubiquitylases in CI is not unique to Wolbachia. Similar enzymes have been implicated in male-killing phenotypes induced by other endosymbionts, such as Spiroplasma. This suggests that interference with the host ubiquitin system may be a common strategy employed by various endosymbionts to manipulate host reproduction (Harumoto and Lemaitre, 2018).The molecular characterization of CI has also revealed the existence of different CI types, depending on the specific Wolbachia strains involved. Incompatibility between strains can be unidirectional or bidirectional, with some strains exhibiting stronger CI effects than others. These variations are attributed to differences in the cif gene sequences and expression levels among Wolbachia strains (LePage et al., 2017).Recent studies have explored the potential applications of Wolbachia-induced CI in pest control and disease vector management. The introduction of Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes into wild populations has shown promise in reducing the transmission of dengue and other arboviruses (Hoffmann et al., 2011). Understanding the molecular basis of CI is crucial for optimizing these strategies and predicting potential evolutionary outcomes.The role of host factors in CI has also been a subject of recent investigation. Zheng et al. (2019) identified host genes involved in CI expression and rescue, suggesting that the interaction between Wolbachia and its host is more complex than initially thought. These findings highlight the importance of considering both bacterial and host factors when studying CI mechanisms.Despite significant progress in understanding the molecular biology of CI, several questions remain unanswered. The exact biochemical mechanisms by which CifA and CifB proteins interact with host cellular processes are still not fully elucidated. Additionally, the evolutionary origins of the cif genes and their potential horizontal transfer between Wolbachia strains require further investigation (Lindsey et al., 2018).In conclusion, recent advances in molecular biology have greatly enhanced our understanding of Wolbachia-induced cytoplasmic incompatibility. The identification of the cif genes and their products has provided a foundation for exploring the mechanisms underlying this fascinating reproductive manipulation. As research in this field continues to progress, it is likely to yield valuable insights into host-microbe interactions, evolutionary biology, and potential applications in pest control and disease management.
